rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we are learning about giving our children praise. 

Praise helps build a positive relationship and encourages good behaviour!

Let’s first reflect on our own experience with praise.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today we are learning about giving our children praise. 

Praise helps build a positive relationship and encourages good behaviour!

Let’s first reflect on our own experience with praise.

text_2.eng: Think about the last time someone thanked you, or said you did something great.

quiz_1_question.eng: How did it make you feel?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Being praised often makes us feel proud.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's great! Being praised often makes us feel happy!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sometimes being praised makes us feel embarrassed, usually because we are not used to it. Remember, everybody deserves praise!

rows.text_2: Think about the last time someone thanked you, or said you did something great.
rows.quiz_1_question: How did it make you feel?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! Being praised often makes us feel proud.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's great! Being praised often makes us feel happy!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Sometimes being praised makes us feel embarrassed, usually because we are not used to it. Remember, everybody deserves praise!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
We all feel better when we are praised.

Praising your child when they behave well will make them want to behave that way more often. 

It also creates a positive and loving relationship between you.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
We all feel better when we are praised.

Praising your child when they behave well will make them want to behave that way more often. 

It also creates a positive and loving relationship between you.

media_title.eng: Tap play to hear how praise can help you and your family

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

When was the last time you were praised? Can you praise yourself for something right now? Praise makes us all feel good. 

It is good to praise our children when they have done well, because when we do that, they will do more of that good behaviour we want to see.

And let's remember to praise ourselves too, for big or small things!

rows.media_title: Tap play to hear how praise can help you and your family
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

When was the last time you were praised? Can you praise yourself for something right now? Praise makes us all feel good. 

It is good to praise our children when they have done well, because when we do that, they will do more of that good behaviour we want to see.

And let's remember to praise ourselves too, for big or small things!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s look at how @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises her son, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, during one-on-one time.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s look at how @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises her son, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, during one-on-one time.

character_1_text.eng: You found one striped sock and one with dots. Let’s find socks that match.

rows.character_1_text: You found one striped sock and one with dots. Let’s find socks that match.
Another sock! This one is white. It’s frustrating to try to find a matching pair when there are so many clothes to look through.

character_1_text.eng: Another sock! This one is white. It’s frustrating to try to find a matching pair when there are so many clothes to look through.

rows.character_1_text: You are being very patient and looking very hard, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. Well done for trying. I am happy you are helping me.

character_1_text.eng: You are being very patient and looking very hard, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. Well done for trying. I am happy you are helping me.

rows.character_1_text:
You found two socks with the same pattern! Well done for not giving up, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name! 

Because you helped me so well, I now have 5 extra minutes to play with you. What would you like to do?

character_1_text.eng:
You found two socks with the same pattern! Well done for not giving up, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name! 

Because you helped me so well, I now have 5 extra minutes to play with you. What would you like to do?

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s reflect on how @data.characters.f3_mother.name praised her son.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on how @data.characters.f3_mother.name praised her son.

text_2.eng: When @data.characters.f3_mother.name gives @data.characters.f3_son_4.name a hug and extra playtime together, she rewards him and encourages him to stay patient and keep helping with chores.

Exactly! When @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, he will want to keep looking for the socks.
All of these options are true!

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: To encourage him to want to help more often

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
Exactly! When @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, he will feel good and be more likely to help with chores in the future.
All of these options are true!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s see what we can learn from HOW @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises her son.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s see what we can learn from HOW @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises her son.

text_2.eng:
@data.characters.f3_mother.name’s praise works because she: 
- 🫱🏾‍🫲🏽 Goes down to @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s level
- 👀 Uses his name and makes eye contact
- 👏🏾 Praises his behaviour right after it happens
- 👍🏾 Praises him for trying, not for the successful outcome
- 💜 Does not criticise his mistake

quiz_1_question.eng: Simple and free rewards can help reinforce praise. What rewards does @data.characters.f3_mother.name use?

rows.text_2:
@data.characters.f3_mother.name’s praise works because she: 
- 🫱🏾‍🫲🏽 Goes down to @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s level
- 👀 Uses his name and makes eye contact
- 👏🏾 Praises his behaviour right after it happens
- 👍🏾 Praises him for trying, not for the successful outcome
- 💜 Does not criticise his mistake
rows.quiz_1_question: Simple and free rewards can help reinforce praise. What rewards does @data.characters.f3_mother.name use?

rows.text_2: That’s right, giving a simple and free reward helps our children to do behaviours that may be difficult for them.

text_2.eng: That’s right, giving a simple and free reward helps our children to do behaviours that may be difficult for them.

rows.text_2: That’s right, giving a simple and free reward helps our children to do behaviours that may be difficult for them.

text_2.eng: That’s right, giving a simple and free reward helps our children to do behaviours that may be difficult for them.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are some easy tips for how to use praise.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some easy tips for how to use praise.

section_1_text.eng: Look for good behaviours that you can praise! It can be anything positive or helpful your child does or tries to do.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Pause and really notice when they are doing something positive. Even if it’s expected of them.

Praise your child for *trying*. This boosts their self-esteem and confidence, which helps them to learn new behaviours.

section_2_text.eng: Praise them when you see them do something you like. Do this every day – even if it’s something really small.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
Tell them specifically what they have done well.

Be enthusiastic and really mean it!

You can show your praise with a big smile and words.

section_3_text.eng: Give your child a simple, free reward to encourage them to do more of the behaviours that may be difficult for them.

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Give your child a hug, extra playtime together, or make their favourite meal. 

Simple rewards can be a big motivation for your child to keep trying and show more positive behaviour.

You can show your praise with a big smile and words.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Now that you have learned a few tips on how to use praise, let’s think of specific things we can praise our children for.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Now that you have learned a few tips on how to use praise, let’s think of specific things we can praise our children for.

quiz_1_question.eng: What is one behaviour your child regularly shows that you can praise them for?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!

quiz_1_option_5_text.eng: Getting ready for school or bed

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!

quiz_1_feedback_6.eng: Whatever you choose to praise your child for is a great choice. You can praise them whenever they have done something well.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Your home activity is to praise your child for at least 2 things every day.
Praise yourself too for all your hard work being a parent – you deserve it!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Your home activity is to praise your child for at least 2 things every day.
Praise yourself too for all your hard work being a parent – you deserve it!

media_title.eng: Tap play to hear how simple praises helped @data.characters.media_female_2.name's family

media_transcript.eng:
When we learned about this praising thing, I thought “We were never praised for things as children, so why should we start now?”. But I got interested when I learned what the benefits of praising could be.

Right after learning about praise, I noticed my son doing what he does every day: Packing away his toys after playing. And I said “Thank you for packing away your toys, my boy, it really makes me happy that you are helping out to keep the house tidy.” My son was smiling and he even came to give me a hug, which he never does. 

This praising business is hard. I still forget to do it sometimes. But praising really makes a difference. I never thought that a simple praise could make such a change in a person!

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you praise your child today?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Parents who practise praise at home get better results!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: You can do it! Try praising your child for something simple at first, like putting away their toy. Praise is a powerful parenting skill!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. With time, giving praise will become easier. Try to praise yourself for something first, like _"Well done for using @global.app_name. It shows you care."_

rows.media_title: Tap play to hear how simple praises helped @data.characters.media_female_2.name's family
rows.media_transcript:
When we learned about this praising thing, I thought “We were never praised for things as children, so why should we start now?”. But I got interested when I learned what the benefits of praising could be.

Right after learning about praise, I noticed my son doing what he does every day: Packing away his toys after playing. And I said “Thank you for packing away your toys, my boy, it really makes me happy that you are helping out to keep the house tidy.” My son was smiling and he even came to give me a hug, which he never does. 

This praising business is hard. I still forget to do it sometimes. But praising really makes a difference. I never thought that a simple praise could make such a change in a person!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! Parents who practise praise at home get better results!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: You can do it! Try praising your child for something simple at first, like putting away their toy. Praise is a powerful parenting skill!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: That's okay. With time, giving praise will become easier. Try to praise yourself for something first, like _"Well done for using @global.app_name. It shows you care."_
